Award.AwardTitle: Comets and the History of Volatile Matter During Planetary System Formation
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant renewal will support high-resolution near-infrared spectroscopic studies of comets in order to test theories about the early formation of the solar system. Comets are remnants from the early solar system that retain the volatiles (ices) from the cold outer protoplanetary disk where they formed. The proposing team will characterize the cometary volatile composition in the near-infrared spectral domain, simultaneously searching for a number of parent molecules via multiple spectral lines of each species; these parent molecules include water, oxidized carbon compounds, symmetric hydrocarbons, and nitriles. They will also conduct complementary searches for deuterated water and deuterated methane in order to constrain the deutrerium-to-hydrogen ratio. The observations will help constrain chemical formation pathways for water and pre-biotic organic molecules in cometary ices, the evolution of volatile matter in the early Solar System, and exogenous delivery of water and pre-biotic molecules to Earth. The project will support undergraduate research and enable student participation in professional astronomical observing runs and in local and national conferences. Also, the team will contribute to the professional development of high-school science teachers in the Washington, DC and Saint Louis, MO metropolitan areas, by conducting a 45-hour workshop on "Comets, Origins, and Life: Interdisciplinary Science in the Secondary Classroom".

POR.DRECONTENT:
Comets are leftovers from the formation of our solar system some 4.5 billion years ago. Like archeologists examine artifacts from the ground in order to understand our past, astronomers look for comets in the sky, but to understand the early history of our solar system. Like archeological artifacts, comets are not pristine, but preserve clues about the processes that occurred when planets were forming that can improve our understanding of how prebiotically important molecules - those that are needed for life to form - were distributed when our planetary system was very young.

We used telescopic observations and a technique called infrared spectroscopy to decode the composition of ices released from comets as they approach and are heated by the Sun and to probe the physical conditions (like varying temperatures) in the expanding atmospheres of these objects. We sensed a suite of molecules, including prebiotically important ones like water and formaldehyde (a chemical precursor of sugars), and reported our findings in a total of thirteen refereed journal papers, several scientific conferences, and two international invited talks (Sweden, Japan). Our findings brought new and important evidence that there are great compositional differences among individual comets in terms of the abundances measured for various molecules. To understand what this compositional diversity might tell us about the early solar system, we successfully initiated a broad international effort between protoplanetary disk modelers and comet scientists, currently hosted by the International Space Science Institute in Bern, Switzerland. Our measurements are being used to inform further development of protoplanetary disk models, which try to explain how prebiotic molecules were distributed while planets were forming.

This project pushed boundaries by studying comets at distances from the Sun (both very close and uncommonly far), where infrared spectroscopy has been very difficult to apply in the past. A study of comet C/2006 W3 Christensen set a new distance record (i.e. how far from the Sun) for identifying two organic molecules (methane and ethane) in a comet by astronomical spectroscopy from Earth-based telescopes. We determined the abundance ratios of these molecules relative to carbon monoxide, which showed one of the highest outgassing release rates ever measured in a comet for this volatile. In the other extreme, we observed comet ISON while it was disintegrating in its rapid approach to the Sun. As the comet outgassing rates were drastically increasing, we discovered significant changes in both temperatures and compositional abundances measured in this comet’s atmosphere. We also performed a deep search for heavy (deuterated) water and constrained its abundances to significant limits, even with a 3-meter class telescope and daytime observing, which is possible with infrared astronomy.

As a feedback to the public which funds this research, the broader impacts of the grant emphasized assistance to science teachers and development of learning tools for both non-science and science students. These tools can be used after the completion of the research award.

At Catholic University of America PI Bonev developed and taught a professional development course for teachers called “Introductory Physics with Photons, Currents, and Relativity”. The course material was also converted to an undergraduate core curriculum and taught at Towson University. These courses use a 21st century perspective to build a concept of the physical world starting with the atomic idea.  This concept is then used to demonstrate how physics is being integrated with biology, chemistry, and astronomy to test the hypothesis that the building blocks of life - water and prebiotic organics - were delivered to early Earth by small bodies like comets.

At University of Missouri – St. Louis [UMSL], graduate student Nathan Roth (mentor: PI Gibb), led a refereed journal paper reporting observations with the Keck 2 telescope. This work strongly suggested that chemical diversity among comets might be more complex than the framework currently used to compare these objects.

We took advantage of the exceptional remote observing capabilities of the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility. A total of 15 undergraduate students and 3 graduate students at UMSL were able to participate in multiple astronomical observing runs over all four years of the award. They took log sheets, controlled the instrument, reduced and analyzed the resulting data, and presented their results at local and regional conferences as well as in a classroom setting. In addition to remote observing, two students travelled to Hawaii to participate in on site observing runs at the W. M. Keck Observatory and IRTF. These hands on opportunities gave students valuable experience pertinent to their future careers as scientists.

PI Gibb gave numerous public lectures and Gibb participated in the UMSL planetarium outreach program, where middle school students are taught about comets, phases of matter, and the night sky. These programs reach several hundred students in the St. Louis metropolitan region each year, many of whom are from under-represented minorities.
